newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIAN EXOTICS - Bullish dollar weighs on regionals.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN EXOTICS - Bullish dollar weighs on regionals.

text.p: Most regional currencies bowed to the dollar's strength on Monday as the U.S. unit continued its upward march, hitting a morning high of 112.85 yen in Tokyo.
In Singapore, the release of trade data showing a slightly sharper-than-expected decline in September non-oil exports added to the Sing dollar's bleak outlook.
But the market showed no immediate reaction to news that non-oil exports fell a nominal 6.2 percent year-on-year in September to S$7.31 billion after falling 6.3 percent in August.
A Reuter poll of 12 Singapore-based economists had predicted a nominal year-on-year fall of 3.4 percent in September.
The Singapore dollar was quoted at 1.4145/55 at 0445 GMT against an opening 1.4140/1.4145.
"The currency's inching rather than steamrolling," said a European bank dealer, adding that the U.S. dollar faced resistance at S$1.4155/60.
He said a sustained break above that level would put the U.S. dollar on track towards a target of S$1.43.
Elsewhere, the Thai baht slipped to 25.492-25.497 at 0445 GMT against 25.488-25.493 late on Friday, but tightened domestic liquidity inhibited active dollar buying, dealers said.
"There was strong bidding for the dollar this morning. But transactions were very limited as tightening liquidity hindered some dollar interest," said a currency dealer in Bangkok.

The Thai overnight interbank rate rose near a one-month high of 13.00-13.50 percent in early trade as the Bank of Thailand's October 22 reserve requirement and speculative dollar buying drained liquidity from the system.
The Indonesian rupiah held steady as players remained wary of a higher fixing by the central bank later in the afternoon.
"Players are taking a wait-and-see attitude on speculation the central bank may raise the fixing rate by one point later today," said a European bank dealer in Jakarta.
The dealer said Bank Indonesia did not usually raise the fixing on Mondays, but last week's unexpected rises prompted players to speculate on a one-point rise.
He said the central bank might raise the intervention and conversion rates by another three points this week.
The intervention rate was set at 2,323.00/2,515.00 and the conversion rate at 2,323.00/2,371 on Friday.
A U.S. bank dealer, however, said some rupiah buying by state-owned banks helped keep the rupiah underpinned.
The Malaysian ringgit remained prey to continuing commercial demand for the dollar, but dealers said activity was likely to be slow ahead of the annual budget on October 25.
"People are expecting a good budget so the ringgit should be stronger. But I'm hearing there's good commercial demand around 2.5050," said a European bank dealer in Singapore.
He said the dollar would need to close above technical resistance at 2.5080 ringgit to head towards a medium-term target of 2.52.
Another dealer said selling interest from funds around the 2.5080 level could slow the ringgit's decline. It was quoted at 2.5069/79 at 0445 GMT against 2.5065/75 on Friday.
-- Madhav Reddy in Kuala Lumpur (603-230 8911), Mantik Kusjanto in Jakarta (6221-384-6364), Anuchit Nguyen in Bangkok (662-652-0642) and Sonali Desai in Singapore (65-8703090)
